ad_hominem.name: Ad Hominem
ad_hominem.description: Attacking the person instead of their argument
ad_hominem.example: You can't trust his economic policy because he's wealthy

appeal_to_authority.name: Appeal to Authority
appeal_to_authority.example: This diet works because a celebrity uses it

appeal_to_emotion.name: Appeal to Emotion
appeal_to_emotion.example: We must ban this because it's scary

false_dilemma.name: False Dilemma
false_dilemma.description: Presenting only two options when more exist
false_dilemma.example: Either support the war or hate your country

begging_question.name: Begging the Question
begging_question.description: Circular reasoning - conclusion assumed in premise
begging_question.example: God exists because the Bible says so, and the Bible is true because God wrote it

hasty_generalization.name: Hasty Generalization
hasty_generalization.description: Drawing broad conclusion from insufficient evidence
hasty_generalization.example: I met two rude people from that city, so everyone there is rude

slippery_slope.name: Slippery Slope
slippery_slope.description: Claiming small step leads to extreme outcome without justification
slippery_slope.example: If we allow same-sex marriage, people will marry animals

equivocation.name: Equivocation
equivocation.description: Using same word with different meanings
equivocation.example: A feather is light; light travels fast; therefore a feather travels fast

affirming_consequent.name: Affirming the Consequent
affirming_consequent.description: If P then Q; Q; therefore P (invalid)
affirming_consequent.example: If it rains, the ground is wet; the ground is wet; therefore it rained

denying_antecedent.name: Denying the Antecedent
denying_antecedent.description: If P then Q; not P; therefore not Q (invalid)
denying_antecedent.example: If it rains, the ground is wet; it's not raining; therefore the ground is dry

straw_man.name: Straw Man
straw_man.description: Misrepresenting an argument to make it easier to attack
straw_man.example: You support welfare? So you think everyone should just sit around and collect checks!

appeal_to_ignorance.name: Appeal to Ignorance
appeal_to_ignorance.description: Arguing something is true because it hasn't been proven false (or vice versa)
appeal_to_ignorance.example: No one has proven ghosts don't exist, so they must be real

appeal_to_tradition.name: Appeal to Tradition
appeal_to_tradition.description: Arguing something is right because it's traditional or always been done that way
appeal_to_tradition.example: We've always done it this way, so we shouldn't change

appeal_to_novelty.name: Appeal to Novelty
appeal_to_novelty.description: Arguing something is better because it's new or modern
appeal_to_novelty.example: This new diet must be effective because it's the latest trend

bandwagon.name: Bandwagon (Appeal to Popularity)
bandwagon.description: Arguing something is true or good because it's popular
bandwagon.example: Millions of people believe it, so it must be true

tu_quoque.name: Tu Quoque (You Too)
tu_quoque.description: Dismissing criticism by pointing out hypocrisy instead of addressing the argument
tu_quoque.example: You say I shouldn't smoke? But you used to smoke!

loaded_question.name: Loaded Question
loaded_question.description: Asking a question that contains an unproven assumption
loaded_question.example: Have you stopped cheating on tests?

false_cause.name: False Cause (Post Hoc)
false_cause.description: Assuming that because B follows A, A caused B
false_cause.example: I wore my lucky socks and we won the game, so my socks caused the win

composition.name: Fallacy of Composition
composition.description: Assuming what's true of parts is true of the whole
composition.example: Each atom in this chair is invisible, therefore the chair is invisible

division.name: Fallacy of Division
division.description: Assuming what's true of the whole is true of the parts
division.example: This car is heavy, therefore each part of it is heavy

amphiboly.name: Amphiboly
amphiboly.description: Ambiguous grammar leads to misleading conclusion
amphiboly.example: Save soap and waste paper (unclear if 'waste' modifies 'paper' or is a verb)

accent.name: Fallacy of Accent
accent.description: Changing meaning by emphasizing different words
accent.example: You shouldn't KILL (implying other harm is okay)

no_true_scotsman.name: No True Scotsman
no_true_scotsman.example: No Scotsman puts sugar on porridge. - 'But my uncle is Scottish and does.' - Well, no TRUE Scotsman does

texas_sharpshooter.name: Texas Sharpshooter
texas_sharpshooter.description: Cherry-picking data to fit a pattern
texas_sharpshooter.example: Looking at only profitable quarters to claim a company is always successful

genetic_fallacy.name: Genetic Fallacy
genetic_fallacy.description: Judging something by its origin rather than its current merit
genetic_fallacy.example: This philosophy is wrong because it was developed by ancient people

appeal_to_pity.name: Appeal to Pity
appeal_to_pity.description: Using sympathy instead of logic to support a conclusion
appeal_to_pity.example: You should pass me because I've had a hard life

appeal_to_force.name: Appeal to Force
appeal_to_force.description: Using threat of force instead of logic
appeal_to_force.example: Agree with me or you'll face consequences

special_pleading.name: Special Pleading
special_pleading.description: Applying standards selectively to favor one's position
special_pleading.example: Murder is wrong, except when our country does it

moving_goalposts.name: Moving the Goalposts
moving_goalposts.example: Show me evidence. [Evidence provided] That evidence isn't good enough, show me more

middle_ground.name: Middle Ground Fallacy
middle_ground.description: Assuming the compromise between two positions must be correct
middle_ground.example: Some say vaccines are safe, others say dangerous, so the truth must be somewhere in between

anecdotal.name: Anecdotal Fallacy
anecdotal.description: Using personal experience instead of sound evidence
anecdotal.example: My grandfather smoked his whole life and lived to 90, so smoking isn't harmful

burden_of_proof.name: Burden of Proof
burden_of_proof.description: Claiming something is true and demanding others disprove it
burden_of_proof.example: I claim unicorns exist; prove they don't!

undistributed_middle.name: Undistributed Middle
undistributed_middle.description: Categorical syllogism where middle term isn't distributed
undistributed_middle.example: All dogs are mammals; all cats are mammals; therefore all dogs are cats

illicit_major.name: Illicit Major
illicit_major.description: Major term distributed in conclusion but not in premise
illicit_major.example: All dogs are animals; no cats are dogs; therefore no cats are animals

illicit_minor.name: Illicit Minor
illicit_minor.description: Minor term distributed in conclusion but not in premise
illicit_minor.example: All mammals are animals; all mammals are warm-blooded; therefore all warm-blooded are animals
